title: Government shutdown: House GOP ponders next move in shutdown fight
content:
House Republicans are beginning to plot what comes next . GOP seeks support for ceiling hike
Top Republicans circled the House floor Thursday afternoon attempting to build support for the debt ceiling bill , the centerpiece of their fall fiscal strategy .
The GOP whip team , led by Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy ( R-Calif. ) , was trying to gauge whether House Republicans would be able to pass a one-year boost of the debt ceiling , alongside a one-year delay of Obamacare and other conservative policies .
But there was opposition from some corners of the GOP conference . Some Republicans said the debt-ceiling package , which is not yet final , doesn ’ t do enough to slow the growth of debt or fails to provide hard limits on how much the federal government can borrow through 2014 .
The House Rules Committee was trying to schedule a hearing Thursday to set parameters for the floor debate on the debt bill , but the timing for that session was unclear .
The debt ceiling is just one piece of a multi-pronged fight over federal spending and debt that has erupted this fall . The federal government shuts down Oct. 1 unless a new funding bill is enacted andthe Treasury Department will exhaust its borrowing authority by Oct. 17 .
Passing a debt ceiling increase with a strong Republican vote total is key to the GOP ’ s strategy . Speaker John Boehner ( R-Ohio ) and his leadership team want to fight for budgetary reforms on the debt ceiling , not the government funding resolution .
But at this point , there ’ s no clear strategy to fund the government . If there ’ s a path to avoiding a government shutdown , no one is talking about it .
Both publicly and privately , House Republican leadership declined to reveal how exactly they will react when the Senate passes its less than two-month government funding-bill , just days before the first shutdown in almost 18 years .
In a meeting of House Republicans Thursday morning in the Capitol , discussion was dominated by responding to the Senate Democrats ’ bill by attaching a provision that would end government subsidies for the health insurance of lawmakers and their staff .
But there was also talk of – and support for – attaching a one-year delay of Obamacare ’ s individual mandate to a government-funding bill when it returns from the Senate either Friday or Saturday , though senators are trying to hammer out an agreement to move even faster .
Speaking to reporters after the meeting , Boehner said “ there ’ s not going to be any speculation about what we ’ re going to do or not do until the Senate passes their bill . ”
Boehner , however , added that he would not accept the Senate ’ s bill , which extends government funding until Nov. 15 , but keeps Obamacare in tact .
The House-passed CR extended funding until Dec. 15 , but stripped out funding for Obamacare . If Boehner sends a bill back to the Senate with any changes , it would raise the chances of a government shutdown next Tuesday . Senate Democrats said on Thursday that they would reject any legislation that tries to chip away at Obama ’ s signature health care law .
Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid ( D-Nev. ) said he and Boehner have not spoken in the last 24 hours — and that there ’ s no need to because Reid will not accept a spending bill with any Obamacare riders .
“ Send us a clean CR , a clean debt ceiling . That ’ s the path forward . There ’ s no need for conversations . We ’ ve spoken loudly and clearly and we have the support of the President of the United States , ” Reid said .
Both chambers might agree to a one-week government funding measure to avoid a shutdown and allow for some more wrangling . Reid refused to answer on Thursday whether he would accept that plan , arguing that right now House members “ do not know what they are going to do . ”
Despite the differences — and lack of an articulated plan — Boehner said he did not “ expect ” a government shutdown to happen . Speaking on the floor Thursday morning , Reid warned Republicans not to shut the government down .
“ Those of us who remember the government shutdowns of 1995 and 1996 know the story didn ’ t end well for Republicans , ” he said .
On a parallel legislative track , though , House Republican leadership is trying to pass their one-year boost of the debt ceiling . In the closed meeting , Republican leadership was bullish on that bill passing , but they found some opposition Thursday .
It ’ s a tough vote for Republicans – they can only lose 17 of their members , as no Democrats are expected to support the legislation . There is some opposition , which Boehner , Majority Leader Eric Cantor ( R-Va. ) and Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy ( R-Cailf . ) think they can overcome .
“ It does not cut spending significantly and it does not fix the problem , ” said Rep. Mo Brooks ( R-Ala. ) , articulating the gripe of some conservatives .
The debt-ceiling legislation is meant to show Republicans that Boehner , Cantor and McCarthy will pick a legislative fight when it comes to boosting the nation ’ s credit limit – even though President Barack Obama has said he is not going to negotiate . The limit needs to be lifted Oct. 17 .
Burgess Everett and Seung Min Kim contributed to this story .

But there was also talk of – and support for – attaching a one-year delay of Obamacare’s individual mandate to a government-funding bill when it returns from the Senate either Friday or Saturday, though senators are trying to hammer out an agreement to move even faster.

Speaking to reporters after the meeting, Boehner said “there’s not going to be any speculation about what we’re going to do or not do until the Senate passes their bill.”

Boehner, however, added that he would not accept the Senate’s bill, which extends government funding until Nov. 15, but keeps Obamacare in tact.

The House-passed CR extended funding until Dec. 15, but stripped out funding for Obamacare. If Boehner sends a bill back to the Senate with any changes, it would raise the chances of a government shutdown next Tuesday. Both chambers might agree to a one-week government funding measure to avoid a shutdown and allow for some more wrangling. Reid refused to answer on Thursday whether he would accept that plan, arguing that right now House members “do not know what they are going to do.”

Despite the differences — and lack of an articulated plan — Boehner said he did not “expect” a government shutdown to happen. Speaking on the floor Thursday morning, Reid warned Republicans not to shut the government down.

“Those of us who remember the government shutdowns of 1995 and 1996 know the story didn’t end well for Republicans,” he said.

On a parallel legislative track, though, House Republican leadership is trying to pass their one-year boost of the debt ceiling. In the closed meeting, Republican leadership was bullish on that bill passing, but they found some opposition Thursday.

It’s a tough vote for Republicans – they can only lose 17 of their members, as no Democrats are expected to support the legislation. There is some opposition, which Boehner, Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) and Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy (R-Cailf.) think they can overcome.

“It does not cut spending significantly and it does not fix the problem,” said Rep. Mo Brooks (R-Ala.), articulating the gripe of some conservatives.

The debt-ceiling legislation is meant to show Republicans that Boehner, Cantor and McCarthy will pick a legislative fight when it comes to boosting the nation’s credit limit – even though President Barack Obama has said he is not going to negotiate. The limit needs to be lifted Oct. 17.

Burgess Everett and Seung Min Kim contributed to this story.
